edit: The percieved War on Christmas is actually just a natural outgrowth of the War Against Chistianity. Which is very real.

Merry Christmas and a Happy Hanukkah next week!

I actually had a conversation with a vendor last week that went like this...

_Her: “Have a great new year, and... uh, that holiday that comes in between.”  
Me: “What Christmas?”  
Her: “Yeah, that.”  
Me: “Yes, Merry Christmas.”  
Her: Awkward pause. “Have a good one.”  
Me: Okay. Um, bye._

What’s with the weirdness! I couldn’t understand it. It was like maybe her boss was listening and she’d get in trouble if she used the C word.

That’s bizarre. Especially since Christmas is all over the place. It’s like this debate over the ’War’ has gotten everyone to think that this is a bigger issue than it is.

On a related note, the House of Representatives [passed a bill to “protect” Christmas](http://web.archive.org/web/20071221093101/http:/blogs.washingtonpost.com/thedebate/2005/12/war_on_christma.html). The ensuing debate is pretty funny and pretty indicative of how ludicrous it is for the U.S. government to pass bills to protect a specific religion.

Wish people a Merry Christmas! Who cares!? Focus on something that _matters_, like any of the laundry list of problems in this country, let alone the world. Christmas isn’t suffering because of “secular” activities, it’s suffering because its practitioners are missing the point. Heck, even [megachurches](http://web.archive.org/web/20071221093101/http:/www.cnn.com/2005/US/12/06/churches.closed.christmas.ap/index.html) are closing on Christmas because of anticipated low turnout due to Christmas falling on Sunday. Who would have guessed that churches themselves would be fighting the war against “the reason behind the season”? Even Fox had ’Happy Holidays’ ornaments for sale on its site before this B.S. crusade started.

As was pointed out by Rep. Gary Ackerman: “Is this another war we fight for reasons that do not exist?” This is not a war against Christmas, it’s the plurality of the United States expressing itself through the democracy of the governing institutions. Welcome to freedom, people. It’s not that you can’t celebrate Christmas, it’s that there are other celebrations going on and people want to acknowledge them. Christians are the overwhelming majority in the U.S. Self-centered individuals are trying to set up the majority as the minority to curry support and money from them. It’s a con, and an old one.

Chris Rugan is right. It is like the “Family Values” thing that gets dredged up every four years. Government has no business telling families what to value. It is just a major smoke screen to keep people from looking at the real problems the Administration has created. They would love to get everyone all up in arms about “saving Christmas” so that they forget about the war and the torture chambers and the unrepresented prisoners in Guantanamo. Religion is supposed to be a matter of personal choice in the “Land of the Free”, not smoke screen to hide the evils that we pursue in its name.

ChrisL

I agree about the plurality...

I don’t think there’s a “war on Christmas” (please can we stop the “war on...” rhetoric in the new year?) but there are definitely people in public institutions (schools, local municipalities) who have been duped by the ACLU into thinking that the C word will get them fired or at the wrong end of a lawsuit. The ACLU is mired in double-speak like every other political organization (and the news organizations)... They’re not out to make room for other religions in schools, they’re just trying to get Christianity out.

”...they’re just trying to get Christianity out.”

Actually, Joe, if I understand their position correctly, it’s just the inappropriate, state-sponsored practice of Christianity in schools that ACLU opposes. (With good reason, in my book.)

Or what is that little swoosh at the bottom?
Oh, and Merry Festivus to all!

Marc, I’m referring to how people (in schools mostly) are sanitizing Christmas out of their “holiday” activities by removing religous symbols and words from songs because they _think_ it’s forbidden by the law. The law simply states that Christmas displays must have both a secular and a religous reference (an angel and a snow man or a santa, for example). And that programs involving singing should include multiple religions (hannukkah for example) and/or have secular songs in the mix (jingle bells).

Given the lawsuits about the pledge this year and over prayer in schools in past years it’s no wonder public officials at local levels are scared and may not understand their rights.
